content:
StatusStrip Class

Definition

Represents a Windows status bar control.

In this Article

[System.Runtime.InteropServices.ClassInterface(System.Runtime.InteropServices.ClassInterfaceType.AutoDispatch)]
[System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComVisible(true)]
public class StatusStrip : System.Windows.Forms.ToolStrip

Remarks

StatusStrip replaces the StatusBar control. Special features of StatusStrip include a custom table layout, support for the form's sizing and moving grips, and support for the Spring property, which allows a ToolStripStatusLabel to fill available space automatically.

The following items are specifically designed to work seamlessly with both ToolStripSystemRenderer and ToolStripProfessionalRenderer in all orientations. They are available by default at design time for the StatusStrip control:

  • ToolStripStatusLabel
  • ToolStripDropDownButton
  • ToolStripSplitButton
  • ToolStripProgressBar

    A StatusStrip control displays information about an object being viewed on a Form, the object's components, or contextual information that relates to that object's operation within your application. Typically, a StatusStrip control consists of ToolStripStatusLabel objects, each of which displays text, an icon, or both. The StatusStrip can also contain ToolStripDropDownButton, ToolStripSplitButton, and ToolStripProgressBar controls.

    The default StatusStrip has no panels. To add panels to a StatusStrip, use the AddRange method, or use the StatusStrip Items Collection Editor at design time to add, remove, or reorder items and modify properties. Use the StatusStrip Tasks Dialog Box at design time to run common commands.

    Although StatusStrip replaces and extends the StatusBar control of previous versions, StatusBar is retained for both backward compatibility and future use if you choose.

Constructors

StatusStrip()

Initializes a new instance of the StatusStrip class.

public StatusStrip ();

Properties

CanOverflow

Gets or sets a value indicating whether the StatusStrip supports overflow functionality.

public bool CanOverflow { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if the StatusStrip supports overflow functionality; otherwise, false. The default is false.

DefaultDock

Gets which borders of the StatusStrip are docked to the ToolStripContainer.

protected override System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle DefaultDock { get; }
Value
DockStyle

One of the DockStyle values. The default is DockStyle.

DefaultPadding

Gets the spacing, in pixels, between the left, right, top, and bottom edges of the StatusStrip from the edges of the form.

protected override System.Windows.Forms.Padding DefaultPadding { get; }
Value
Padding

A Padding that represents the spacing. The default is {Left=6, Top=2, Right=0, Bottom=2}.

Remarks

Use the DefaultPadding property to set the interior space between controls. When a control is a container of items, padding represents the space from the edge of the container.

DefaultShowItemToolTips

Gets a value indicating whether ToolTips are shown for the StatusStrip by default.

protected override bool DefaultShowItemToolTips { get; }
Value
Boolean

false in all cases.

DefaultSize

Gets the size, in pixels, of the StatusStrip when it is first created.

protected override System.Drawing.Size DefaultSize { get; }
Value
Size

A stem.Drawing.Point.#ctor* constructor representing the size of the StatusStrip, in pixels.

Dock

Gets or sets which StatusStrip borders are docked to its parent control and determines how a StatusStrip is resized with its parent.

public override System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle Dock { get; set; }
Value
DockStyle

One of the DockStyle values. The default is DockStyle.

Remarks

Use the Dock property to define how a StatusStrip is automatically resized as its parent control is resized. For example, setting Dock to DockStyle causes the StatusStrip to align itself with the left edges of its parent control and to resize as the parent control is resized. Controls are docked in their Z-order, which is the visual layering of controls on a form along the form's Z-axis (depth).

A control can be docked to one edge of its parent container or can be docked to all edges and fill the parent container.

GripStyle

Gets or sets the visibility of the grip used to reposition the control.

public System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripGripStyle GripStyle { get; set; }
Value
ToolStripGripStyle

One of the ToolStripGripStyle values. The default is ToolStripGripStyle.

Remarks

Even with the SizingGrip property set to true and the GripStyle property set to Visible, the sizing grip will not be displayed unless you also set the LayoutStyle property to one of the overflow values. If the LayoutStyle property is set to ToolStripLayoutStyle or ToolStripLayoutStyle, the sizing grip will not be displayed.

LayoutStyle

Gets or sets a value indicating how the StatusStrip lays out the items collection.

public System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripLayoutStyle LayoutStyle { get; set; }
Value
ToolStripLayoutStyle

One of the ToolStripLayoutStyle values. The default is ToolStripLayoutStyle.

Remarks

Use the LayoutStyle property to get or set how items are arranged on the StatusStrip.

Padding

This property is not relevant for this class.

public System.Windows.Forms.Padding Padding { get; set; }
Value
Padding

A Padding value.

Remarks

This property is not relevant for this class.

ShowItemToolTips

Gets or sets a value indicating whether ToolTips are shown for the StatusStrip.

public bool ShowItemToolTips { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if ToolTips are shown for the StatusStrip; otherwise, false. The default is false.

Remarks

Use the ShowItemToolTips property to get or set ToolTip display behavior.

SizeGripBounds

Gets the boundaries of the sizing handle (grip) for a StatusStrip.

public System.Drawing.Rectangle SizeGripBounds { get; }
Value
Rectangle

A Rectangle representing the grip boundaries.

SizingGrip

Gets or sets a value indicating whether a sizing handle (grip) is displayed in the lower-right corner of the control.

public bool SizingGrip { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if a grip is displayed; otherwise, false. The default is true.

Remarks

You can use the SizingGrip property to display a grip to provide an indication to the user of when a StatusStrip is resizable.

Even with the SizingGrip property set to true and the GripStyle property set to Visible, the sizing grip will not be displayed unless you also set the LayoutStyle property to one of the overflow values. If the LayoutStyle property is set to ToolStripLayoutStyle or ToolStripLayoutStyle, the sizing grip will not be displayed.

Stretch

Gets or sets a value indicating whether the StatusStrip stretches from end to end in its container.

public bool Stretch { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if the StatusStrip stretches from end to end in its ToolStripContainer; otherwise, false. The default is true.

Methods

CreateAccessibilityInstance()

Creates a new accessibility object for the control.

protected override System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject CreateAccessibilityInstance ();
Returns
AccessibleObject

A new AccessibleObject for the control.

Remarks

If you do not explicitly call the CreateAccessibilityInstance method, it will be called when the AccessibilityObject property is referenced.

Note

To get or set the AccessibilityObject property, you must add a reference to the Accessibility assembly installed with the .NET Framework.

CreateDefaultItem(String,Image,EventHandler)

Creates a default ToolStripStatusLabel with the specified text, image, and event handler on a new StatusStrip instance.

protected override System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripItem CreateDefaultItem (string text, System.Drawing.Image image, EventHandler onClick);
text
String

The text to use for the ToolStripStatusLabel. If the text parameter is a hyphen (-), this method creates a ToolStripSeparator.

image
Image

The Image to display on the ToolStripStatusLabel.

onClick
EventHandler

An event handler that raises the Click event when the ToolStripStatusLabel is clicked.

Returns
ToolStripItem

A stem.Windows.Forms.ToolStripStatusLabel.#ctor(System.String,System.Drawing.Image,System.EventHandler), or a ToolStripSeparator if the text parameter is a hyphen (-).

Remarks

Use the CreateDefaultItem method to add a ToolStripStatusLabel with commonly used characteristics to a StatusStrip.

Dispose(Boolean)

Releases the unmanaged resources used by the StatusStrip and optionally releases the managed resources.

protected override void Dispose (bool disposing);
disposing
Boolean

true to release both managed and unmanaged resources; false to release only unmanaged resources.

Remarks

This method is called by the public Dispose()method and the Finalize method. Dispose() invokes the protected Dispose(Boolean) method with the disposing parameter set to true. Finalize invokes Dispose with disposing set to false.

When the disposing parameter is true, this method releases all resources held by any managed objects that this StatusStrip references. This method invokes the Dispose() method of each referenced object.

OnLayout(LayoutEventArgs)

Raises the Layout event.

protected override void OnLayout (System.Windows.Forms.LayoutEventArgs levent);
levent
LayoutEventArgs

The event data.

OnPaintBackground(PaintEventArgs)

Paints the background of the control.

protected override void OnPaintBackground (System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs e);
e
PaintEventArgs

A PaintEventArgs that contains information about the StatusStrip to paint.

Remarks

Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see Events.

The OnPaintBackground method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

OnSpringTableLayoutCore()

Provides custom table layout for a StatusStrip.

protected virtual void OnSpringTableLayoutCore ();

Remarks

Override OnSpringTableLayoutCore to do custom table layouts. The default value of ToolStripLayoutStyle is ToolStripLayoutStyle.

SetDisplayedItems()

Resets the collection of displayed and overflow items after a layout is done.

protected override void SetDisplayedItems ();

WndProc(Message)

Processes Windows messages.

protected override void WndProc (ref System.Windows.Forms.Message m);
m
Message

The Windows Message to process.

Remarks

The Message structure wraps messages that Windows sends. You can use this structure to wrap a message and assign it to the window procedure to be dispatched. You can also use this structure to get information about a message the system sends to your application or controls.

You cannot create the Message structure directly. To create a Message structure, use the Create method. To make creating Message structures more efficient, the Message structure uses its pool of existing Message structures instead of creating an instance of a new one, if possible. However, if a Message structure is not available in the pool, a new instance of the structure is created.

Events

PaddingChanged

This event is not relevant for this class.

public event EventHandler PaddingChanged;

Remarks

This event is not relevant for this class.
